Commissions cling to trades involving ETFs, as they do with stocks, a toll paid to the guardians of the market. But the bounty is rich, the variety of funds as vast as the prairie sky. For the astute wanderer of finance, it's wise to test the promised treasures, to see if the riches of diversification truly lie within, and to what extent they shine. In this pursuit, we shall turn our gaze to the ETF IHF, measuring it against the ten stalwarts that form its heart, to see if the wealth of a solitary ETF matches the spread of a diverse portfolio of ten, or if there lies a better gathering of stocks, a more bountiful harvest of return.

To weigh the value of this ETF, we shan't burden ourselves with the entirety of its holdings, choosing instead the top ten, which account for a sturdy 63.58 percent of its assets. Below, the names of these ten and the weight they carry.

In seeking to understand how these ten stocks mirror the spirit of the ETF IHF, we can use the current percentage of assets, tempered to a full hundred, to reckon each stock's gift to the portfolio's Beta and Return, were the portfolio solely made of these ten, aligned as the ETF has drawn them. The numbers, their truths laid bare, follow in the chart below.

From this chart, a tale unfolds. A portfolio of the top ten holdings yields a return 6.11 percent richer than the ETF, a bounty grown by 16 percent. The Beta, that measure of risk, sits .12 lower than that of the ETF entire. Thus far, the path of the ten might promise more gold with less peril. Yet, the specter of uncertainty remains, for it might be that the means of these two collections are not so different in the eyes of statistics.

To discern if these paths truly diverge, we must measure the variance of each of the ten stocks, each brought to the same scale, to compare their gathered variance to that of the ETF IHF.

In the darkening months of the year, when the world turns inward and the frost seals the earth, there was a notable waning in the entries of the commuter logs, as if the very spirit of the undertaking had been smothered by the bleakness of winter. It was a thing to ponder, the reasons elusive as smoke on the wind. The cold had come, biting, to the New England campus, and it seemed to drive the people from their bicycles and their paths, back to the warmth of their cloistered lives, away from the open air where the breath is visible before the mouth in ghostly plumes. December, too, is a month of reckoning, a time when scholars and educators alike are bound up in the fever of final tasks, their minds a whirl of grades and closing acts. The simple act of recording their transit fell away from them, lost to the shadows of pressing duties. Then comes the holiday tide, the world turned over to celebration and pause, the halls empty themselves of their inhabitants, who are drawn away to their own sanctuaries, far from the tasks of academia.

And so, with the coming of the spring semester in January's late days, one might expect a return, a resurgence of purpose. Yet February was a barren month for logs, the emptiness unexplained by reason alone. Perhaps it is the nature of such endeavors, to blaze brightly at inception and then to flicker as the days wear on. To stir the embers, we conjured the Carpool Challenge Week in March, a breath of life into the fading project, and for a time the logs filled again. The challenge then, as we found, was to sustain the fire through the quiet times, through the breaks and the lulls that are the very rhythm of the academic year.

There is another truth, deep and woven into the fabric of our lives—the allure of the automobile, the freedom it promises. It is a part of us, this independence, and so to draw folk away from their beloved cars, we offered gifts. Certificates for meals and coffee, for books and massages, small tokens to entice. Yet one wonders what might have been, had we offered greater temptations—a bicycle, a hybrid, an electric car. The prizes held steady through our months, and perhaps therein lay a misstep. Had we promised more as the year drew on, the engagement might have swelled. In December, a bicycle perhaps, and in the new year, a car that whispers of a future kinder to the earth. Such dreams might have kept the spark alive.

In the dim chambers of memory, I found myself wandering through the archival corridors of the Library of Congress, seeking out the early Edison films—a collection of trickery captured from 1895 to 1901. These films, fifteen in their number, spun illusions through the deft hand of creative editing. My gaze was drawn to the poetics of these early trick films, noting the evolution that marked the outliers which dared to step beyond the bounds of their time. There was a steadfastness to these trick films, each one confined within its set, framed by the unyielding proscenium, the lens unmoving, capturing long and medium shots, each one a solitary vision. Yet, at the dawn of a new century, a few dared to defy, weaving multiple shots into their fabric. 

What you see often in these films is a stage, an interior set that holds its ground, the camera fixed as if it were a sentinel. It does not stir to follow the actors who move side to side, tethered to the stage like marionettes. Such was the way of the world then, the celluloid borrowing from the theater, from vaudeville and the art of illusion. The stage, it seems, was a cage, holding the performers from straying towards the camera, from breaching the fourth wall. Consider Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel (1900), where the players dance along the horizontal plane, never advancing, never retreating, and the camera holds its watch, unmoving. 

This proscenium composition casts the shots in long takes, seldom granting the intimacy of a medium shot. Close-ups are a stranger in this world, the audience left to witness the performance in its entirety, as if seated in the velvet shadows of a theater. Actors remain distant, middle ground their domain, never venturing closer to the lens that captures them. 

In these early days, each film a solitary shot, a single breath caught on film. These trick films, brief as a flicker, often mere minutes in length, constrained by the ceaseless ticking of frames. Their stories, if they can be called such, are but glimpses of vaudeville—magic acts, vanishing acts, transformations caught in the spotlight. Yet, within this singular shot in the viewer's eye, lies a truth unspoken—a dance of cuts and splices to conjure the apparition, to vanish the seen. Witness The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots (1895), and you may discern the seam where the magic is stitched, though to the eye it is as one.

In the realm of the Gothic Novel, there exists a peculiar conundrum, an oxymoron of sorts, the "Old-New," as Ian Watt names it in his musings on the genre's rise. This Gothic mode has been both scorned and revered, condemned for its shallow roots and exalted for the terrible sublime it conjures, as Burke might say. The first of its kind, Horace Walpole's The Castle of Otranto, wove together the threads of the ancient and the modern, birthing a new order of literary expression. Walpole reached back to the old stagecraft and intertwined it with the mimicry of nature that the modern novel embraced, calling it "A Gothic Story." The genre, steeped in echoes of medieval theater and architecture, carried the weight of old traditions. Even in Otranto's time, "gothic" was a word bandied about to describe a myriad of peoples, styles, and epochs. It was seen as relic-like, unsophisticated beside the gleaming advancements of modern society and literature. Yet, it is this blend of the old, theatrical Gothic with the new narrative form, offering an intimate glimpse into the psyche of its characters, that allows the Gothic to endure, to be at once obsolete and novel to readers far removed from its origins.

Among the tenets of the Gothic is the notion of Chivalry—an idea both preserved and reshaped in Walpole's tale. This medieval code, the making of a knight both brave and just, was a beacon for Gothic scribes, representing an ideal lost to the ages. Walpole, writing amidst political tumult and shadowed by accusations, clung to this vision of chivalric virtue, perhaps sensing its absence in his own world. Within his pages, characters like Frederic embody this ideal, appearing as the paragon of knightly virtue, a prince marked by suffering and tragedy, thought to have fallen to infidels. Here is the gallant and courteous Knight, exaggerated in form, setting the stage for the Gothic's future dalliance with excess.

The world of supply chains is a silent orchestration, a stream of processes that move like a river through the landscape of commerce. From the moment a customer places an order, the journey of goods begins, winding its way through raw materials, supply, production, and distribution until it reaches the waiting hands of the consumer. It was in the pale light of 1982 that Keith Oliver, a consultant, gave a name to this intricate dance—supply chain management. He spoke of the planning, the execution, and the oversight that is required to meet the needs of customers swiftly and without falter.

There are six pillars upon which this vast structure rests: production, supply, inventory, location, transportation, and information. These are the tools by which managers craft their art, each decision a brushstroke on the canvas of customer service.

Production is where it all begins, the bedrock upon which the entire supply chain is built. Here, the when and the why, the where and the how, all take shape. Managers look to the market, that ever-shifting sea, to discern the desires of the customer. They read its currents and decide what should be made and how much of it. The place of creation is chosen with care, each plant selected for its ability to meet the demands of volume and quality, with the customer's satisfaction as the guiding star. Workloads are scheduled, machines are readied, and the wheels of production turn. Every detail is a thread in the tapestry, for if any are missed, the cost, in time and money, could be great.

I remember my own time at Wal-Mart and Target, those sprawling empires of retail. Each had its own design, a booklet, a process for every part of the business. A uniform laid out just so, shipments received with a precision that left no room for error. These outlines, these maps, they allowed the company to move smoothly, without the confusion that so often accompanies a lack of direction.

The next pillar is supply, a realm of strategic decisions that determine the core capabilities of a facility. From these decisions, partnerships grow, some within the company, others outsourced to those beyond its walls. Each division, each piece of equipment, each worker, all are chosen for their fit in this grand design. Sometimes, work is handed to others, a choice made in the name of velocity—the ability to maintain quality and flexibility while keeping costs low. It is a decision made in the quiet of a manager's mind, a choice that sends ripples across the surface, unseen but felt.

In this world of interwoven paths and unseen connections, the supply chain moves ever forward, a testament to the silent artistry of those who guide it.

In the heart of Victorian literature lies an intricate tapestry woven with meticulous detail and an unwavering gaze upon the aristocracy. Yet, among these grand narratives, two novels stand apart, Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights, each straying from the beaten path, weaving mystery and the bizarre into their fabric. This deviation lends a peculiar strength to their characters, unraveling the depths of their motives and baring the raw sinew of their emotions. 

There comes a passage in Oliver Twist where bewilderment and confusion clamber over the mind like shadowy specters. Young Oliver finds himself ensnared between Sikes and Crackit, their angry voices lingering in his ears, a dreamlike echo of reality. He speaks to them as if they were there, flesh and bone, until suddenly the crack of gunfire shatters the air. Cries and shouts rise up, a tumult of noise and light, as unseen hands whisk him away. Through this tempest of visions, an unrelenting pain gnaws at him, a torment unending.

The novel drifts into these dreamscapes, these ethereal realms, to unearth truths buried within Oliver, to peel back the layers of what torments him, and to reveal his understanding of the world’s grim visage. When the gunshot that felled Oliver returns to the fore in chapter 28, it is relived in a vivid, dreamlike state. The experience underscores the powerlessness that grips him, the precarious state of his health reflected in the spectral figures of Sikes and Crackit that haunt his fevered mind. The gunshot overwhelms him, his senses dulled, and yet he feels the unseen hand that carries him, a constant pain now intertwined with fear, not the surprise of a sudden wound. There arises the question of whose hand guides this misfortune, for it is not Oliver’s own. This event fortifies the notion of his helplessness, a boy adrift, unable to seize the reins of fate even as his life hangs by a thread. A creeping despair gnaws at him, as if old Fagin has begun to weave his dark spell, sapping Oliver’s will to fight, bending him to this despair, shackling his spirit. For otherwise, one might think Oliver would strive, if only for the preservation of his own life.

As one day bleeds into the next, night descends, a cloak of dread. Time stretches and contracts, a silence both endless and fleeting, each hour slipping by like a ghost in the dark.

In the days gone by, I found myself working in a place that was a tether for young minds, a sanctuary in the after hours where children sought knowledge. They came with their books and their questions, and I did my part to guide them through the labyrinth of words and numbers. My realm was English, the art of reading, and it was there that I was summoned to aid a boy named Adrian. His troubles with words were peculiar, a mystery wrapped in the simplicity of childhood. Some letters he conquered with ease, while others eluded him like shadows in the twilight. He was a child of Latino descent, his tongue fluent in the language of this land, yet there was a chasm in his reading that we could not bridge. 

It was not until his mother came that the fog lifted. She spoke only in her native tongue, Spanish, and with my meager grasp of her language, we managed to communicate. And it was then that the truth came to me, simple and profound as any revelation. Adrian did not falter in reading; he merely stumbled upon an alphabet unfamiliar to his home. Whether this realization changed his path, I cannot say. But I hold hope that the boy found his way.

I tell this tale to shed a light on the barriers that rise in the halls of learning, especially here in California. It is a reminder that the obstacle is not always as it seems. Even a child fluent in the spoken word may find reading to be a mountain steep and unyielding. The problem is known to all, yet the solution remains elusive. For Adrian, the answer lay in tutoring, a simple path through the maze of letters and sounds. But for many, the journey is more complex, with no single beacon to guide the way. The truth is woven in the tapestry of dual language systems, immersion, tutors, and ESL classes. None alone can mend the breach; together, they hold the key.

The dual language system, an idea with promise, not just for those whose first words were in Spanish, but for all children. Studies have shown that children in such programs rise above their peers. Yet fear cloaks this idea, whispers of wasted resources and benefits lost on the many. But this is not the truth. If such programs were the rule, not the exception, all would find gain in their embrace. But how do we traverse this path? Should we demand all teachers to speak in two tongues? Such a notion is folly. Yet, there is no reason we cannot have those who walk beside the children, guides fluent in both worlds, to aid them on their journey.

From the time we are small, they tell us of a world beyond our own, vast and unfathomable, a realm of mystery where answers are sought in the pews of the faithful or in the silent chambers of the heart. Some of us take with open hands the doctrines handed down by our kin, while others turn away, denying the beyond in favor of a solitary universe where the self reigns supreme. We wander from one creed to another, casting off the old like a snake shedding its skin, always searching for a meaning that fits. We seek not just the light but the shape of ourselves that this light might reveal, a beacon against the encroaching dark.

A cardinal, my father whispered when I asked him which bird sang sweetest to his soul. We sat there on the porch, the rain drumming on the tin above like the slow march of time. Smoke curled upward from our cigarettes, mingling with the damp air. The rainwater coursed down the gutters, drowning the flowers at the porch's edge. He stared into the rain, eyes lost in some distant place, memories flickering like shadows on a cave wall. His frame had withered, clothes hanging loose on his thinning body, hair sparse as the leaves in November. He looked past me, through me, and I felt the chill of solitude, the words lodged in my throat unspoken, for to speak them was to give truth to the fear gnawing at my heart. I drew close, and together we watched the June rain fall, a silent communion.

The December that followed stole him away, five days beyond the mark of my twenty-second year. The treatments had carved more time from the stone, yet the worth of those days lay heavy with suffering. What kind of God, I wondered, metes out such cruelty? In the stillness of night, I found no solace in prayer, the thought of a listening deity long since abandoned.

I could not bear witness to his crossing from this life to the next. I chose not to. I wished to hold in my heart the father who lived, not the shadow of his leaving. I knew him better than any, better than those who gathered to mark his passing, and knew he would not have wanted his child to see the light fade. Alone, I curled in my bed for three days, waiting for the words that never came.

No one called. The world turned, indifferent.

In the quiet vastness of fields stretching far and wide lay the heart and mind of John Taylor of Caroline, a man bound to the soil and the creed of Republicanism. His hands, once upon plowshares, turned briefly to the affairs of state, crafting a voice unyielding in its clamor for freedom's breadth and the restraint of government. His was a vision rooted deep in the earth, an agrarian truth shaping his every thought on sovereignty, the Constitution, and the laws that govern men.

Taylor saw in the burgeoning land of America a canvas unmarked by the traditions of old, a place where the ideal of self-rule might flourish. He spoke of natural rights, bound inexorably one to another, each fragile as a sparrow's wing, and should one be clipped, the others falter and fall. These rights, he argued, must remain untouched by the hands of governance. In the wild state of nature, strength and cunning reigned supreme, yet in the realm of civilization, such a hierarchy must not stand.

To forge his vision of society, Taylor called for a governance that acknowledged the light and shadow within each soul. He held steadfast to a morality of duality, proclaiming that as men wielded power, their virtues and vices were but reflections of themselves. Good governance, he claimed, lay in the safeguarding of property, the nurturing of the land, and the tempering of unchecked capitalism. Though all men were driven by self-interest, it was only sin when it transgressed beyond the welfare of the commonweal into realms of exploitation. A righteous government would bind man's darker intents, though it too must be watched lest it stray into wickedness.

In the manner of the staunch Republicans of his age, Taylor demanded a strict reading of the Constitution, a Federal power constrained by the words therein, no more, no less. For a sprawling Federal reach was costly and prone to tyranny. Yet he knew that mere literalism was fraught with peril, a path to corruption unless the spirit of the framers guided its course. To Taylor, the Declaration of Independence was the true covenant, for it spoke plainly of a union of sovereign states, not a single nation.

Thus, John Taylor stood, a man of the land, his ideals as wide as the horizon, as enduring as the earth beneath his feet, ever guarding the fragile balance between liberty and authority.

He stood there staring downwards, his mind a blank canvas trying to comprehend the sight before him. Unfeeling, silent, the practiced gaze of one who observes without attaching meaning, his mind dissected the scene laid out before his eyes. Thoughts drifted in and out, faster than they came, seamless and smooth, leaving him to wonder if they were his thoughts at all or merely a stream of consciousness that flowed unbidden through his being.

There was a time, long ago, when an artist he'd known told him to buy a book, The New Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain. He'd sought to learn the art of drawing since he was a child of six, and the book promised to teach everything from the understanding of a pencil to the brain's perception of lines. One lesson it taught was to encase any image within a square frame, turning the chaos of a complex view—a bowl of fruit on a table in a kitchen adjoining a dining room—into something simple and comprehensible. That bowl of fruit on a plain, uncomplicated plane.

Yet now, as he gazed down at the bowl before him, he found no such frame in his mind. Overwhelmed, awed, he could do nothing but stand there, wonderstruck. They spoke of Picasso's blue period, Monet's love of green, the Renaissance masters' spectrum of color. If he fancied himself worthy of the Artistic, then before him lay the genesis of his canvas, the inception of his tale, his own Work in Brown.

His fingertips brushed the tool of his artistry, muscles tensing and relaxing as his hand moved through the air, the will of his mind taking form in what might have been the most creative moment of his life. Water swirled, serene and smooth, crystal clear. Flakes of matter broke away, carried off to oblivion. His muscles tensed again, more swiftly, more anxiously, as his hand struck once more at the lever. But the stubborn brown mass clung to the bowl's bottom like a slug.

Mop in hand, feet planted a foot apart, the green tie uncomfortably tight around his neck, he frowned at the crude parcel of processed animal and plant left as a message for the hapless souls tasked with cleaning Rite Aid's restrooms. A few more flushes, a few more moments of introspection, then his hand reached for the wall, grasping the end of the toilet paper, wrapping itself until it resembled an oven mitt. Straightening, then bending at the waist, his hand descended into the bowl, like a mother reaching into an oven for the Thanksgiving turkey.

In the dim corridors of the world, young souls find themselves behind the wheel, where the shadows of fate and inexperience converge. The youngest among us, these tender drivers, are caught in a deadly dance, a tapestry of statistics woven with the threads of their youth. The National Institutes of Health speak of this, a tale told by the very architecture of the adolescent mind, unready for the perils that lie in wait on the open road. Inexperience, too, is a silent companion, whispering of rollovers and roads left behind, of speed that outpaces wisdom.

In the company of their peers, they fare worse still, a truth known by any with a flicker of insight. The Southern California Injury Prevention Research Center lays bare the correlation, a grim ledger of age against the tally of accidents. California, among others, seeks to shield them, crafting provisional licenses to bind their hours and bar their young companions. Yet these measures are but fleeting gestures against the storm. The truth of it is stark: these youngest travelers, by any reckoning, are ill-equipped for the burdens they bear.

Psychologist Marvin Zuckerman casts his gaze further, deeming eighteen too tender an age. USA Today echoes his findings, of a yearning in those beneath nineteen for the thrill of risk, a hunger that outpaces caution. And so, reason whispers of delay, of holding back the keys until the fires of youthful daring cool. Elsewise, we face a future of lives scattered on the asphalt, a toll of loss that threatens to climb, as the children of Baby Boomers come of age, a legion ready to claim the road.

The path forward is clear and unbarred by complexity. Schools might still teach the ways of the wheel, planting seeds for drivers yet to come. But the road itself would wait for those under eighteen, a privilege postponed. A provisional permit, a precursor to full freedom, could be their guide, with hours of training to temper the journey. The number of these hours might echo the requirements of states like California, where six hours behind the wheel and fifty in practice are the norm.

The specter of youth behind the wheel spans the nation, and so should our response. Uniform laws, national in their reach, could shield our young from coast to coast. In this, there is nothing new, only the quiet wisdom of prevention, a shield raised against the dark.

In the dry and clinical corridors of understanding, this paper walks through the shadowed paths of Central Auditory Processing Disorder, known to some as CAPD. It first sets forth a definition, brief as the breath of a dying wind. Then it turns to the matter of diagnosis, laying out the common signs, the red flags, as they are known. Lastly, it speaks to the teachers, those guides in the mainstream classrooms, on how they might shepherd a student afflicted with this disorder.

Central Auditory Processing Disorder, or by another name Auditory Processing Disorder, whispers of the workings of the central nervous system, the brain's dance with sounds. It is the efficiency, the effectiveness, with which this system uses what is heard. Narrowly drawn, (C)AP concerns itself with how the central nervous system perceives auditory information, the neurobiological chorus behind this, and the strange electric potentials that it births. Simply, it is a disorder where the brain, the very seat of our understanding, cannot properly weave the sounds into meaning. Those who carry this burden hear as others do, and thus are not named among the hearing impaired; rather, it is the brain's translation of sound, the separation of words from noise, that falters.

The earliest whispers of this disorder trace back to the mid-1950s, spoken of then as "auditory imperception." It was a time when researchers turned their gaze to children with communicative disorders. In 1954, an Italian trio, Bocca, Calearo, and Cassinari, began crafting tests for such children. By 1961, Kimura brought forth dichotic testing, crafting a model to explain the physiology of the central auditory nervous system, the CANS, that underlies dichotic perception. A national conference in 1977 stirred the waters of research further, drawing attention to children with CAPD.

CAPD shows itself in manifold ways. Those touched by it may find sound an elusive specter, unable to place it in space. They may struggle to tell apart two or more acoustic events, each sound occurrence a puzzle. Recognizing sound patterns may elude them, and detecting changes in speech, the subtle sarcasm that rides on a change of voice, may pass unheard. One sound might be swallowed by another. They may lack the ability to synthesize sound clues, interpreting them in a way that invites action, and might also be unable to discern the sequence in which auditory information is presented.

To diagnose CAPD, one must peer through a lens of systematic observation, watching the listening behaviors and performance on tests of auditory function. A host of voices—those of audiologists, SLPs, psychologists, and others—use various measures to evaluate auditory-related skills. This may be done with questionnaires, surveys, and observations of how the patient responds to stimuli. Yet, as of now, there is no singular instrument, no test wielded with consistent success, and the cause of the disorder remains a mystery. Many tests present the patient with a cacophony of simultaneous auditory stimuli, asking them to pick out certain items, like a series of words or numbers. More advanced tests listen to the echoes within the ear, measuring the responses to these acoustic signals.

In the quiet corridors of my aspirations, I find myself drawn to the path of social work, a calling whispered by the winds of compassion and resolve. My heart beats to the rhythm of service, a cadence of respect and ethics, a melody of commitment not just for others but for the growth of my own soul. These values stand as sentinels in my journey toward aiding the Division of Family and Children Services, where I seek to be a beacon for children lost in the shadows of neglect and a guide for families wandering amidst their own storms.

In my early days, the direction was uncertain, a landscape of choices veiled in mist. High school and college unfolded, revealing to me a world where many fled from their demons, seeking solace in illusions that offered none. In these moments, I chose psychology, a lens to peer into the human heart. Yet, upon the completion of my studies at Piedmont College in that summer of 2009, I found myself at a crossroads, the road ahead obscured until fate intervened.

It was a day like any other when I met a boy, sixteen and burdened by the weight of his home. He sat on the couch, the air heavy with the silent cries of his spirit. His tale was one of escape from hands that should have nurtured but instead brought harm. The law stood silent, impotent in the face of his cries, and so I stepped forward, my voice a plea for understanding. I spoke to the parents, their words a tapestry of excuses, each thread woven with denial. It was then, amidst the echoes of that encounter, that the path of social work unfurled before me, a road paved with the resolve to untangle such "simple" disputes.

Justice, a word often spoken and seldom understood, burns in me like a flame unyielding. Society, in its contradictions, lauds the individual yet molds us in its image. In my defiance, I have colored my hair in hues unnatural, worn garments that spoke my truth, pierced the ears of convention, and stood with the GSBA, a banner against the tides of prejudice. I am an individual, bound not by the chains of tradition but by the call of justice. My journey will continue, a protest against the injustices that stain our world.

And so I walk this path, a wanderer with purpose. Each step echoes with the resolve to heal, to guide, to uplift. For in the end, it is not the road we travel but the lives we touch that define us.

In the depths of night, when the world lay shrouded in a quietude so absolute, there stirred a restlessness born not of choice but of the very marrow of one’s being. This paper delves into the realm of insomnia, exploring the paths carved by the Biological and Sociocultural models upon the landscape of this affliction. The Biological model speaks of the whispers of ancestry in the blood, of genetic blueprints passed down, of the corporeal maladies that bind us. In contrast, the Sociocultural model weaves its tale of the world without, of the ties tethered to the air we breathe, the lands we walk, the myriad faces and stories that shape our lives. It is here that we lay bare the findings, dissecting each study, each scrap of knowledge, to better illuminate the models’ truths, their flaws and their merits.

A sleep disorder, a specter that shadows the mind, may arise as a solitary beast, or it may be the handmaiden of other specters, other disorders that dwell within the psyche. These primal sleep disorders, Dyssomnias and Parasomnias, they speak of nights where the body rebels, where sleep neither comes nor stays, or where it comes unbidden, like a thief in the night. Dyssomnias, they are sleep's betrayals—Primary Insomnia and Primary Hypersomnia, Narcolepsy with its sudden surrender to the abyss, Breathing-Related Sleep Disorder, the misaligned rhythms of Circadian Rhythm Sleep Disorder, and the vagueness of Dyssomnia Not Otherwise Specified. Parasomnias, they are the dreams that walk the earth—Nightmare Disorder, the terrors, the somnambulist's path, each a tale of sleep entwined with waking. And there are others, linked to the disorders of mind, the Axis I and Axis II maladies, where sleep is but another casualty. This review, it peers into the heart of insomnia, seeking the threads of these models amidst the tangle.

In the Biological model, the tale is one of the flesh and the blood, of the genes that sing in silent harmony, shaping the night’s repose. Neurons nestled within the hypothalamus, they hold the key, the orexin that orchestrates the dance of sleep and wakefulness. In the laboratory's sterile light, they watched the mice, saw how phenotypic GABAB receptors played their part upon the orexin neurons. The activation of these receptors, by GABAA, a siren song that lulls to sleep. When silenced, anxiety slumbers and sleep takes hold. Baclofen, the GABAB agonist, it stretched the hours of sleep (Matsuki et al., 2009). These findings, they whisper of a kinship between the mouse and the human, a shared fate written in the genetic code. The absence or flaw of this receptor, it could spell a lifetime of nights unfulfilled without the balm of medicine. And in the Sociocultural sphere, the implications ripple outward. If this trait be inherited, then it shapes a life, a destiny where sleep is elusive, where the waking hours grow heavy with fatigue, casting shadows over the endeavors of life, the labor and the mundane.

Thus is the story told, of insomnia through the lens of these models, a tapestry woven of the threads of biology and the patterns of the world beyond.

In the time since I've taken root here at University Park, near three years now or the span of four and a half semesters, I've come to know the lay of the land, its paths and ways, and found them wanting. For many, myself included, the act of moving from one end of this sprawling campus to the other is fraught with challenges. Back in my freshman days they set me down in an East Halls dormitory, a place so far flung it lay nearly at the eastern edge of the campus, save for the stadium and the Bryce Jordan Center. The trek from Stuart Hall, my abode, to the likes of the Willard building, toward the heart of campus, could stretch nigh to a half hour on foot, more so when the weather turned sour, which it often does in this town called State College. I spoke once with an alumnus, not much older than myself, who told tales of a time when East Halls stood apart, separated by vast swathes of barren land. Now that emptiness is filled, sports fields and grand new edifices rising, the Creamery and a health services building, apartments encircling all. As the campus grows, so too does the struggle of traversing it. What might be the answer to this vexation of movement? On such a ground as this, the bicycle is king. Yet the bike alone is no balm. The students must mount and ride, and the campus must be shaped to meet the needs of those who pedal.

I spoke with a friend, one who has taken up cycling again after years of neglect. He mused aloud, puzzled at his own forsaking of it. "Bicycles are remarkable," he said. "There was a time when it seemed uncouth to ride, yet it's the only way to traverse these distances." Beyond the boon to one's own flesh, bicycling is the swiftest means to journey. A bowl of oatmeal, a bit of sweat, and you'll cover miles aplenty. Like many others, I dwell off campus now, as far from its center as some dormitories lie. This year the wisest choice I made was to procure a bicycle. Each day finds me in the Thomas building, a place that by foot is a lengthy march of twenty-five minutes from my dwelling. A bicycle cuts that time to a mere five if I push the pedals with vigor. Yet Pollock Road, the most direct path to Thomas from my abode, is no easy ride. There's merit in walking, sure enough, but time is a luxury I lack. Without my bike, I'd be left with walking as the sole reliable means to reach my classes. To stride to Thomas each day would steal an extra half-hour or more from my time, a toll of over two and a half hours each week. Factor in the minutes spent walking to other classes, to meetings, and so on, and the cost is more than I can afford.

In the land where Aldous Huxley sets his tale, the world has become a place estranged from the sanctity of the individual. A place where the hum of machinery and the relentless drive of the market have forged a new order. Brave New World, he called it, and yet it was anything but. The people there, molded from birth to seek only the fleeting joy of the moment, their souls traded for comfort and convenience. They are but pieces on a board, moved by unseen hands, their lives dictated by the grand design of the World Controller. To peer through the veil with the eyes of Marxist thought is to see the shadows cast by Huxley's suspicions of the rising tides of technology and commerce. The words of Marx echo in the fabric of the story, terms like reification and hegemony serving as signposts pointing to the flaws of an economy still in its infancy during Huxley’s time.

In this world, capitalism is laid bare, skinned to its bones by the concept of false consciousness. The people, blind to the strings that bind them, care only for their own gain, their understanding of class relations blurred. It is the work of ideological sorcery, the masses conditioned to believe in their own supremacy as long as they toe the line, consume, and adhere to the dictates of the World Controller. The lower echelons, the Deltas and Gammas, know not their masters, their wills bent and broken by the whispers of hypnopædia. The Alphas and Betas, aware yet inert, accept their roles, save for the few like Bernard who dare to dream otherwise. Here, the dance of social classes speaks volumes of the perceived chains of capitalism, shackling the soul and spirit alike.

In this world of Huxley’s creation, true kinship is a ghost long laid to rest. Characters drift through the narrative, ghosts of depth and dimension, as if Huxley suggests that the march of technology and the creed of capitalism rob man of his will and his heart. Love is a relic, emotions dulled to the point of oblivion. Men speak of women as objects, their worth measured by their appearance, the women recounting their encounters with a stark detachment. Each class, snug in its place, mirrors the socioeconomic chains of capitalism. Their unwavering fealty to their role in society mirrors the Marxist view of the proletariat, convinced of their worth as long as they consume, conform, and march in step with their fellows.

It was almost four years past when I took a course in Islam at CBC, a time when the room would fill with debates that would rise and fall like the breath of a sleeping beast. The question that burned most was whether Islam bore the face of hostility. That question has not withered with the passage of days but grown more relevant, as if nourished by the events since the shadow of 9/11. I have watched the great machine of mass media shift its gaze from a stance of hostility toward Islam's fervent sons to a tolerance so extreme it perches on the brink of oblivion. In that year of 2001, it seemed that a man with the name Borac Obama, with roots tangled in the rich soil of a Muslim heritage, might never have stood in the light of candidacy for the presidency.

The life of the Prophet, as laid bare in his biography, pulls at the threads of intrigue within me. It tells a tale that seems at odds with the man history has long whispered to me. In the echoes of my learning and knowing, I was led to believe that Muhammad pressed his faith upon others like a blacksmith hammering iron into the shape of his will. They spoke of a man who would conquer and claim tribes, bending them to the creed of Islam. Yet, the recounting of his life paints him in hues of a martyr, misunderstood and humble in his dealings. People, it says, came to him, drawn by the 'truth' that shone from his teachings as moths to the flame.

There are stories woven into this tapestry of his life that bear resemblance to the ministries of Jesus and the wonders that followed in his wake. Chief among them is the tale of mutton and milk multiplied, a bounty feeding forty men. It strikes me as a deliberate echo, a desire to cast Muhammad as a prophet of humility, one who walked in miracles without the need to prove his worth. This troubles me, for it seems a theft of the life and light of Jesus Christ, an attempt to claim that sacred story through the shadow of another.

The biography is littered with tales, an agenda of witness and conversion, yet many are told from distant voices, echoes of so-and-so who heard from so-and-so. Such accounts, meant to bolster truth, instead unravel into suspicion, casting shadows on their veracity.

What gnaws at me most is the lifting up of Muhammad as a man of godly virtue, humble and wise, gentle in his ways. History, as I have known it, speaks a different tale, one of power and conquest, and I wonder if those who follow him today know the true shape of the man who carved their path.

In the time after the passing of the Nazarene, the path of thought that bore his name wandered far from the teachings he once imparted. A man might stand at the river's edge and trace the flow of Christian thought as it drifted from its wellspring, a current unmoored from the life that once was. The world now reflects a burgeoning consciousness, a stir of minds unshackling from the ancient fetters of tradition. Yet, there are those who cling to the teachings instilled within them, their voices a whisper against the gale of change. But these voices may not rise loud enough to steer the course of what is to come. Among the faithful, an understanding will swell, a longing to peel back the layers of time and see the truth of the man whose name they bear. It will be a slow turning, like the grinding of the earth beneath the stars, but turn it will. The tide of history will shift, flowing backward to the time before doctrines encased the light of his words. A movement will arise, each hand pulling away the veils of creed until what remains is the simple vision of what the Nazarene spoke of in the name of the divine.

As this great reversion sweeps through the lands of America and Europe, men and women will gather to worship not in the ways of kings or popes but as those who walked beside him. The church, an ancient bastion, will guide them still. Yet with this backward journey, the myriad beliefs that once spread like branches will draw together, each branch reaching for the same root. Across the lands, across the divides of belief, the differences will fade and a new sameness will take their place. History tells of reversions such as these. Was not the Roman Empire once the persecutor, now a vessel of faith? Did not this nation rise from the bondage of a people to their ascension in its leadership? In days to come, such a reversion will unfold within the faith, a cleansing of the many in search of the one. It is vital to understand that this path backward will be marked by a reading of his words as parables, not law. And so we ask, what has transpired since those days of the Nazarene?

To look back, far back, is to find the cradle of faith in the Jewish tradition, the theological forebear of the Christian line. Monotheism, the sacred bond of revelation, the authority of the scriptures of old, these were the pillars upon which the faith stood as the Romans marched into Jerusalem in the year of 63 before the Common Era. Yet, even then, the children of Israel were not of one heart. They were divided, the Sadducees and Pharisees, the Essenes and Zealots, and the many who walked the common paths.

In the pages of The Jungle, Upton Sinclair lays bare the raw sinews of human nature, exposing the intrinsic greed and self-interest that lurks within. Man toils not for the betterment of all but to elevate himself above the rest, blind to the plight of those beneath him. The sprawling factories stand as monuments to this greed, their owners and overseers caring little for the souls crushed in their relentless pursuit of greatness. These edifices rise against the sky, the chimneys belching smoke that trails to the world's end, a testament to the havoc wrought without heed or care for man or beast. The poison they spill forth and the waste that runs unchecked from the pens of Packingtown are of no concern to those who rule over them.

These captains of industry, steely-eyed and unyielding, care not for the flesh and blood that swell their coffers. The workers, little more than cogs in a vast machine, are squeezed for every ounce of worth. This cauldron of envy and hatred knows no loyalty, no decency, where a man is naught but a shadow against the gleam of a dollar. They labor under the whip of hours unending, cast aside without notice, left to fend in a world uncaring. Laws to shield them are but dreams, and the managers wield their power unchecked, driving men to the brink in pursuit of progress. The book does not speak it plainly, yet the message resonates—the souls who ground themselves to dust in Packingtown were left to the mercy of their harsh fate, bereft of aid or counsel.

Unions rose like false prophets, promising salvation, yet often they too sought their slice of flesh. The workers, caught in this web, were likened to slaves, shackled to a system as brutal and indifferent as any master of old. Here stood a populace, foreign and lowly, teetering on the edge of want, bound to the caprice of men as ruthless as the slave drivers of yore. In such a world, immorality is not a choice but a certainty, as inevitable as the tides, as pervasive as the shadows cast by the relentless advance of industry.

In the somber expanse of Edgar Allan Poe's poetic endeavors lies "Dream-Land," a work he held in high regard. Within its verses, the word "Thulé" appears in the sixth and fifty-sixth lines, a term traced by Mabbott to the ancient Virgil. Virgil spoke of Thulé as an island beyond Britain, the fringe of the known world to the Greeks. That Virgil wielded the term is beyond doubt, yet another source casts its shadow upon it, one more modern, yet steeped in the past. Poe, with his gaze ever turned toward the Germanic realms, was drawn to their authors as a moth to flame.

A particular passage illuminates Poe's acquaintance with the writings of Goethe. Karl J. Arndt, in his musings on Poe’s "Politian" and Goethe’s "Mignon," remarks upon the kinship of their verses, suggesting an echo of Goethe in Poe's own cadence. The Oxford Companion to English Literature speaks of Goethe, that luminary of letters, whose opus, the poetic drama "Faust," found daylight in two parts, the first breathing in 1808, the second exhaling in the fateful year of Goethe's passing, 1832. Nestled within the latter part of "Faust" is a brief poem, "The King of Thulé." It tells of a monarch whose queen's departure leaves him bereft, clinging to a goblet she gifted him. In his grief, he drowns his soul in drink, the specter of his queen ever beside him. At last, he bequeaths his realm to his progeny, save the goblet, casting it into the sea before closing his eyes forever. The king in Goethe's verse and the figure in Poe's "Dream-Land" stand as shadowed twins, perhaps reflections of Poe's own loss and solace found at the bottle's bottom. A romantic drama by H. P. Grattan in 1842 rendered "Faust" anew, mere months before Poe let Thulé slip into "The Pit and the Pendulum."

Poe spoke of Thulé twice across his works. In "The Pit and the Pendulum," he invokes "ultima Thule," and in "Dream-Land," the term bookends the poem, framing its spectral journey. "The King of Thulé" and "Dream-Land" could be read as kin, each echoing the other's lament. In "Dream-Land," the speaker wanders through a Thulé of shadows, a barren realm haunted by shades of the past, devoid of hue and warmth. These vistas mirror those in Goethe’s "The King of Thulé," where the king, bereft of queen and purpose, treads a twilight path. Poe's verse seems to step into Goethe's own, a pilgrimage through shared sorrow.

Goethe's name would have been known to Poe, if not through his own reading, then through the admiration he held for Tennyson, who in turn revered Goethe. When asked of Tennyson, Poe's words betray his respect. But beyond Tennyson lay Goethe's own work, a tide of translations and adaptations flooding the literary world following its initial release. In this tide, Poe surely found himself adrift.

In the land of California where laws are like the shifting sands, a question arises from the commonplace yet portentous act of slipping on applesauce in a grocery store. Could a customer, bruised by such a fall, find in her favor punitive damages when the store's steward acted with malice, having twice been told of the spill and yet left it unattended for the span of a half-hour, his mind more on his supper than on his duty? 

The hand of the judge may not easily sweep away Jennifer Palmer’s plea for punitive recompense. To bring forth such a claim, the plaintiff must unfurl evidence that the offending party acted with a willful and conscious neglect of the harm likely to ensue, and that such conduct bore the mark of contemptible disregard. Palmer might argue that Martin, the keeper of the store, should have foreseen the peril of neglecting the spill, for in the months before her misfortune, others had fallen prey to similar slips; yet with this knowledge, he did nothing. While her assertion that Martin’s actions were vile may find less favor, it remains plausible given the record of six such mishaps in that year of 2009, with Martin unmoved to safeguard his domain.

The thirteenth day of October, as the clock struck five in the evening, brought word to Rich Wayne, a worker of D&D Markets, who told his master, Paul Martin, of the applesauce strewn upon the floor. Martin, wrapped in the trappings of his dinner break, dismissed the warning as he had none other. A quarter hour passed and Mary J. Haddigan, another underling, brought the same news, and again Martin brushed it aside. At half past five, Jennifer Palmer met the floor with a grievous injury. Her fall was the sixth such calamity to mar D&D’s halls in that year alone. She now seeks not just redress for her wounds, but also a reckoning of punitive nature, and the question weighs on whether a motion might bar such a plea.

In the jurisprudence of California, one may claim punitive recompense for breaches outside the bounds of contract when the wrongdoer is guilty of “oppression, fraud, or malice.” So speaks Cal. Civ. Code, § 3294(a). Malice, as the law would have it, is marked by intent to harm, or lacking such intent, by conduct “despicable” and wrought with “willful and conscious disregard for the rights or safety of others.” Courts have deemed conduct malicious when the actor, aware of the likely peril of his ways, willfully ignored the chance to avert it. Such was the wisdom of Taylor v. Super. Ct. of Los Angeles Co., where the court’s words echoed through the halls of justice.

She had always felt a certain lack, a yearning unquenched, a quiet gnawing at the edge of her being. It began when she was but fourteen, standing on the threshold of a life not yet lived. And still it lingered three years on, at seventeen, an age where the world lay waiting to unfold its mysteries. By then she had come to understand it was not a thing she sought but a someone. Yet no boy had stirred her heart. Some had approached her, stumbling through rituals of courtship with the un-woo-able, but none had kindled the fire within. Often she questioned herself, grappling with the enigma of her own heart, searching for reasons that eluded her grasp. Years of contemplation had yielded theories, but none substantial enough to anchor her musings. So she carried on, her life a tapestry of questions, her desires a riddle unresolved.

A day at home was typically serene, a refuge of calm. Her parents, gentle souls, rarely clashed, their lives a testament to quiet harmony. Arguments with their daughter were rare, a testament to her free spirit and independent nature that occasionally brushed against their tranquil ways. She was the light to their stillness, her vibrant personality a beacon of warmth, her kindness drawing others to her like moths to a flame.

But today was not such a day. As she wandered from room to room, seeking inspiration like a pilgrim seeking grace, the peace was shattered by a scream from the kitchen, her mother's voice cutting through the air like a blade. Panic rising within her, she ran to the source, calling out, "Mom?! Mom, what's wrong?!" She found her mother on the floor, pain written across her face, each breath a whispered "Ow." Kneeling beside her, she offered her strength, her touch a balm. "Ouch ... swee - ty, I ... need you to take me to - the hospital." The words were labored, pressed from her lips by the weight of her suffering. "Okay Mom, just tell me where I can pick you up." Her mother gestured weakly, and in that moment, the daughter was grateful for the strength she had honed. She lifted her mother, carried her to the car, laid her gently in the back, and drove into the unknown.

The hospital loomed, a fortress of antiseptic and dread, but her mind was a singular focus, the world narrowed to the task at hand. She carried her mother inside, her voice rising above the din, calling for aid. Faces turned, concern etched in every line, and hands reached out to help, a rolling bed brought forth to bear her mother away. They took her swiftly, and the daughter was left in the echo of her own worry.

Her mother had fallen, a simple slip from a stepping stool while reaching for a vase perched high in the cabinet, an act of grace turned to folly.

In the vast ledger of human endeavor, a study rose from the depths to speak of a thing called the Mediterranean Diet, a name that might hold a promise of heart's deliverance. In its essence, a covenant of sustenance fashioned from the earth's bounty, wherein an alternate Mediterranean score stood, marking one's fidelity to this way of eating, and with it, a whisper of hope against the scourges of chronic heart disease and the shadow of stroke. A diet born of the old soils and sunlit shores, it bade folk to partake more deeply of the plant's gifts, laying aside the heavier fare of beasts. Fruits and nuts, whole grains and legumes, they sang of life, while the monounsaturated riches of olive and fish kept watch over the heart's chambers. A draught of wine was not spurned, for moderation was its own kind of virtue.

There had been those who came before, chronicling the Med way's virtue against the toll of life and heart, and they spoke of it as one might speak of a balm more soothing than the low-fat creed. Yet the specter of stroke, its sudden and silent visitation, had not been fully reckoned with.

So it was that this study journeyed alongside 74,886 women, aged 38 to 63, whose lives were woven into the Nurses' Health Study, a great tapestry of 121,700 souls strewn across 11 states. From the year 1984 to 2004, six times did the women recount their dietary ways through food frequency reminiscences, a testament to what they had consumed in the year gone by. Most stayed the course, their stories enduring through the years. These accounts were measured against the truth of medical records and the solemnity of death's certificates, seeking the stark reality of heart and stroke. When records slipped from the grasp of certainty, probability held sway, marking 17% of strokes and 24% of heart attacks as likely but unconfirmed. The weight of their bodies, the smoke of their habits, the aspirin in their veins, and the hormones post-menopause were all tallied, alongside the stride of their leisure's exertions.

To chisel away the noise of fleeting indulgences and uncover the heart of long-term sustenance, the diet scores were averaged over time, like the slow accretion of silt in a riverbed. Adjustments were made for those factors that might cloud the truth, accounting for age and smoke, body and mind, movement and stillness.

They wielded the tools of Cox proportional-hazard modeling, separating the wheat from the chaff, to discern the link betwixt a Mediterranean way and the specter of heart and stroke. Separate models for the fatal and the nonfatal, each a different path through the dark wood.

And so it was found, in this tale of years, that the women who embraced the Mediterranean ways, those in the highest quintile, faced lesser peril from heart's betrayal and stroke's grasp than those who did not. For in 20 years, 2391 cases of heart's onset, 1763 strokes, and 1077 deaths by the heart's and stroke's hand together were chronicled. The top quintile stood with a relative risk, a measure of their lesser fear, at 0.71.

Such was the tale writ in the annals of science, a story of bread and breath, of olive and vine, and of the enduring hope for heart's reprieve.

The sign stands in the dust and sun, proclaiming a tale of Hitler alive in Burma. Ellen Page, the actress known for the film Juno, stands solitary at a street's edge, her hands lifting a sign of cardboard, the message thereon scrawled in Sharpie, unsettling and stark. Burma, a land also named Myanmar, lies in the heart of Southeast Asia, governed by a ruthless junta that seized its power in the year nineteen sixty-two, a power born of a coup d'état, and held ever since in iron grip. In the year two thousand and seven, the streets bore witness to protests, the first in a decade's time. Led by monks, saffron-robed and resolute, these protests earned their name, "The Saffron Revolution." And the people gathered, their interest piqued by the monks' call, the government at first begrudgingly allowing such gatherings, peaceable as they were. But peace is a fragile thing, and violence brewed like a storm, the military turning against the monks, monasteries torn asunder. Foreign journalists found their freedom forfeit, imprisoned on sight. Among them, a Japanese photojournalist, Kenji Nagai, fell, slain for nothing more than bearing witness to the tumult. Official accounts speak of thirteen dead, but Colonel Hla Win, who turned from the army's ranks, claimed far more, bodies beyond counting, the toll climbing into the thousands.

Such is the world's way, the old tale told anew. Atrocities like these are no stranger to the pages of history. The hunger of those in power to stifle dissent, to clutch their rule tight upon the throats of the people, is a tale as ancient as civilization itself. The emperors of Rome, in their marble halls, proclaimed themselves touched by the gods, their power absolute. In Japan, emperors claimed divinity, gods walking among men, guiding them to prosperity, be it through the making of motors or the ritual of hara-kiri. Even now, in the land of the free, George W. Bush, president, speaks each week to Ted Haggard, a voice for foolishness worldwide, a group beneath the banner of the Republic Party.

The chronicles of history hold many such accounts. The year nineteen eighty-nine saw the protests of June Fourth at Tiananmen Square, where thinkers and laborers and students joined in chorus against the government's iron rule. The numbers of the dead are as uncertain as shadows, from the government's count of a scant few hundred to the Red Cross's claim of thousands. In Rwanda, the nineties bore witness to genocide, the Hutu militias, with government aid, casting a net of death upon the Tutsis, upon any who dared to hold a moderate line, their ethnicity a matter of indifference to the killers. And then, across the years and the lands, Hitler's 'Third Reich' stands as a grim monument, a time and place where Jewish lives were hunted down, extinguished, the world a witness to horror.

In the dim recesses of time and sound, Duke Ellington stands as a figure of enduring grace and vision, his presence in jazz a testament to the long shadow he cast. His hands upon the piano whisper more than they shout, crafting a delicate tapestry where notes hang like stars in the night, each one a testament to his boundless creativity. The orchestra was his canvas, and he painted with the souls of men, drawing out their hidden colors, their secret voices. In the quiet spaces between the notes, you could hear the echoes of something eternal, a music that spoke of the earth and the sky and the spaces in between.

Ellington was a master of shaping sound, of bending it to his will, and in his compositions, you could find the space for a man to breathe, to improvise, to find himself in the music. He laid down the bones of the thing and let his players drape it in flesh, each note a heartbeat, each phrase a breath. The orchestra was his choir, and he knew their voices as well as his own, fitting them together like stones in a wall, each one lending its strength to the whole.

In the pages of the Grove Music dictionary, his name is etched in reverence, a testament to the innovation he brought to the world. Creole Love Call is a song that lives and breathes, a testament to his ability to use the voice as an instrument, weaving it into the fabric of the music until it became one with the whole. In this piece, you hear the echo of a time when music was raw and new, and each note was a step into the unknown.

The song unfolds in a series of choruses, each one a chapter in a story told without words. The call and response of the first chorus is a conversation between the voice and the reeds, a dialogue that begins in softness and ends in a roughened edge. The muted trumpet of the second chorus speaks in blue notes, a language as old as the earth. The clarinet of the third chorus rises like smoke, the piano a soft heartbeat beneath it. The full band returns in the fourth chorus, echoing the call and response, the brass and reeds in a dance of sound. The fifth chorus climbs to a peak, the reeds in their high register, the brass and rhythm sections a heartbeat beneath. The sixth returns to the beginning, the voice a growl, an instrument in its own right. And in the end, a brief tag, a vocal run, a trombone's dissonant farewell.

Hot and Bothered, a year later, is another chapter in this story, a testament to his ear for tone and color. In the call and response between “Bubber” Miley's muted trumpet and Baby Cox’s scat singing, you hear the voice and the instrument as one, a rich tapestry of sound. It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing) takes these ideas and stretches them, lets them breathe, the muted trombone of Joe “Tricky Sam” Nanton a voice in its own right, a melody that dances in the air.

In Ellington's hands, the music was alive, a living thing that breathed and moved and sang. His legacy is written in the notes that linger in the air, in the echoes that fade into the night, a testament to a man who saw the world in sound and shaped it with his hands.

Why do creatures bend their shapes to the passage of time, twisting and changing as they do? What unseen hands guide the course of their metamorphosis? Though a century has passed since D'Arcy Thompson mused that the zoologist had yet to fathom the simplest of forms with numbers, we stand today only a step beyond his shadow. Yet, there are those who have dared to drape the cloak of mathematics over the slow dance of mollusk bones, tracing their life and lineage in numerical dreams. Our study peers into this enigma, seeking the secret mechanisms behind the evolutionary dance of Prunum, wielding both math and experiment as tools of revelation. We took to the bones of Prunum, captured in their ghostly X-rays, and from these spectral images, we drew the lines of their existence, feeding these measures to the CerioShell. From this sorcery of numbers, we conjured visions of shells that might be, a map of what might lie along the edges of their possible forms. These visions we blend with the raw truth of experiment and observation, grasping for a deeper understanding of the grand play that unfolds in this lineage.

In the mind's eye, a shell is but a tube bending through the void, each turn a chapter of its silent story. These turns, these whorls, spiral around an invisible spine, the columella, the core of its being. The whorls grow at their own pace, a seam drawing the boundary of each, a suture. The last whorl, the body whorl, is the grand finale, and what came before is the spire, crowned by the apex, the base resting at the opposite end. From the aperture, the creature within reaches out to the world.

A shell reveals itself in many faces: apical, basal, apertural, abapertural. The apertural view, the usual face, shows the opening wide, the apex pointing to the heavens.

Counting whorls is a ritual. View the shell from above, find the first suture's birth. With a line, divide the world of the shell, and from this line, count the whorls, each a quarter of the whole.

Think of the shell as a journey of openings across time, as the beast within builds its fortress. We trace this path with the coordinates of the center of each whorl's mouth, charting the course of its growth.

This path is drawn in lines and numbers. With the formulation in hand, we can play the role of creator, adjusting the threads of the mollusk's bone-making.

In the land of Indonesia, where the sun rises over a tapestry of islands, the cries of newborns and the silence of those who do not survive hold a quiet constancy. For a decade now, the rate of neonatal and infant mortality has lingered in the shadows, unmoved by time's passing. The nation strides forward on paths laid by the Millennium Development Goals, reaching toward the waters and the promise of sanitation. Yet, the road to the health of child and mother remains rugged, the milestones unmet, the journey long. Herein lies the tale of a system in need of fortification, not of isolated remedies.

In the birthing rooms where life begins, there are changes. A skilled hand is now present in seventy-two percent of births, a mark of progress. But the hands of tradition still hold sway, midwives attending without the tools to quell the bleeding that claims mothers in its sorrowful embrace. The numbers tell a tale half-true, a mirage of progress that fades upon closer view. Elsewhere, the scourge of diarrhea in the young is met with fewer healers, the decline marked in the records of the land. Postnatal care, a flickering concern, is scattered and sparse across the archipelago.

The knife of the cesarean-section, a lifeline in times of peril, finds its place in the world of the city, but in the countryside, it is a stranger, known to only two percent. The chasm between urban and rural yawns wide, a testament to inequity, a tale of access bound to place. The wealth of the land, too, divides the people; the richest step forward while the poorest stand in shadow, a full twenty-seven percent behind, barred by the cost of care.

As the nation contemplates the path ahead, the question looms large. Shall the focus narrow to the needs of mother and child, or shall the fabric of the whole be strengthened? The allure of targeted programs is strong, their goals clear and their pace swift. Yet, the cost is a shifting of resources, a neglect of the whole for the part, a tale of divided strength. The lessons of the world echo with warnings, the tale of funds for one disease draining the life from another. As programs multiply, they splinter, uncoordinated, a forest of forms and papers where once there was purpose.

Thus, the path forward must be chosen with care, for the lives of the young and their mothers rest upon the decision. The tale of health in Indonesia is a tale of many roads, each leading to a future yet unwritten.

The world of Popular Music has stretched and sprawled over the last century, its branches reaching out into so many genres that one is hard-pressed to name them all. Entangled in its own growth, each genre—be it rap, rock, country, jazz, or folk—has birthed its own progeny, sub-genres and sub-sub-genres spiraling within its confines. If one were to argue, Heavy Metal within the rock sphere has become a most diverse and expressive form of popular music over the past forty years. It is expressive for it lays bare the breadth of human emotion, though it often treads the shadowed path of the spectrum. Its diversity came quick on the heels of its inception, as folk realized its pliability and seized upon it to forge their sub-genres, and onward to sub-sub-genres, a chain unbroken to this day.

Now, here we stand amid the heavy metal movement, a landscape so riddled with niches and enclaves that to define heavy metal is a task fraught with uncertainty. It has absorbed themes from beyond its borders, yet it all began somewhere. To grasp the essence of the metal that pervades the air today, one must first comprehend the very movement of metal, why it is movement and not mere genre.

Metal, in its essence, is a movement cloaked in darkness. It is music born of excess—more bass, more volume, more violence, more spectacle. It offers less of the primitive, more of the skilled; those who play in metal bands are masters of their craft, and their mastery resonates through their sound. Metal too is, though it may surprise none, a movement steeped in the haze of drugs. The psychedelic surge of the mid-seventies drove souls to madness, birthing strange, unearthly records, with drugs as the scapegoat for their creation. It bears many a dark and visceral quality, a novelty in the musical scene where popular tunes often shied from the shadows of the emotional spectrum. Subsequent generations of metal drew from these dark, visceral veins, echoing the Romantic Era's brooding heart. Lyrics such as those penned by Byrne speak to this darkness, foundational to the movement.

The lines of Helter Skelter reveal the murkier depths of the Beatles. It swings with a rhythm of highs and lows, a reflection, some say, of drug-induced states. This song is heralded by some as among the first of Heavy Metal, a retort to a Rolling Stones track that also treaded heavily and darkly. The Beatles sought to prove their mettle against the Stones, and thus, Helter Skelter found its place on The White Album.

In the time before the surrealists spun their dreams on canvas, Henri Rousseau was crafting his own visions, both in the world of paint and in the quiet chambers of his heart. The Dream, a painting born in 1910 from Rousseau's hand, offers not just the image of a woman bewitched by the landscapes of her slumber but also stands as a testament to Rousseau's own desires and battles. In his pursuit of acclaim and understanding from the world of art that he so longed to join, he grappled with a choice: to mimic the forms and styles beloved by critics or to carve his own path, stark and solitary. The Dream stands as a mirror to this struggle, reflecting his quest for acceptance against a backdrop of independence.

To gaze upon The Dream with understanding, one must first walk a little in Rousseau's shoes, to know the life from which his art sprang. Born May 21, 1844, in the town of Laval in the northwest of France, Rousseau was the son of a tinsmith, a hardware dealer who enjoyed the modest comforts of the bourgeoisie (Shattuck 47). In his youth, art was a stranger to him, for he had no formal schooling in its ways. Instead, he served the state as a gabelou, a toll collector, until he was forty, though he earned the misnomer of douanier, a customs inspector (Shattuck 46). The death of his first wife, Clémence, and the loss of eight of their children left him alone save for a daughter, Julia, and a heart heavy with sorrow (Shattuck 49). It was to painting he turned, seeking solace and a new beginning, untouched by the romantic visions of peasants that his peers often portrayed. He was a folk painter, carrying the dreams and hopes of his own class.

Rousseau's yearning for acceptance in the hallowed halls of art is not hard to grasp when seen in the light of his circumstances. He was not only self-taught and late to the canvas but also creating in an era filled with other bright stars. Recognition came slowly, arriving in the shadow of Matisse, who was already making his mark. In Modern French Painters, Jan Gordon writes of the two as both rivals and contrasts, not just in their art but in the very soul of their painting. Matisse feared the mundane, while Rousseau sought to paint in such a way that he might be welcomed into the ranks of the Artiste Français (92).

The old thinkers would have you believe in some tether betwixt the good and the beautiful. That one cannot be without the other. And so it may be. As Keats penned on that ancient urn, truth and beauty are a single breath. All we know and all we must ever know. Life teaches us much through its harsh lessons and its brief joys. Yet there are things, ethics and aesthetics among them, that we know without knowing how. They are not learned, but felt. A painting or a poem, a moment of grace or kindness. They are not rules to be followed but things to be understood in the marrow. We try to speak of them, to capture them with words, but words fail. They are shadows on the cave wall.

Consider da Vinci's Mona Lisa. You can talk of its lines and its colors, its place in time, but those words fall short of its truth. Ask someone why they love a painting or a poem and they will tell you there is something about it. Something beyond the reach of words. O'Connor knew well the power of story. A story tells what no statement can. It is not a list of attributes but a doorway. Ethics, too, are such a doorway. Wittgenstein spoke of ethics as beyond the realm of words, a thing transcendent. It is this transcendence, this ineffable quality, that binds art to morality. They are of the same cloth, woven in the shadows.

We feel the truth of art and ethics in a place beyond the senses. They touch the soul in ways the mind cannot explain. Literature, above all arts, carries this weight. It bears a moral heart that others may not. Music and painting, they have their beauty, but literature holds a mirror to the soul. It reflects our values, the choices we must make. It is vital because it shows us who we are. What we cherish. What we fear. In its pages, we find the truths we cannot speak but only live.

The Germany of today, a land drawn from the depth of its own history, rises like a colossus from the shadowed alps of München to the northern whispers of Kiel by the Baltic sea. This tapestry of culture stretches from Köln along the Rhine, winding through the heart of the country to Dresden's Saxon embrace on the Elbe. Yet beneath this unity lies a story of disparate tribes and origins converging upon a single narrative.

Germania, the ancient soil of the Germans, bears a name shrouded in the mists of scholarly debate. Tacitus penned the tale of the Tungrians, a tribe once bearing the name of Germans, who crossed the Rhine to clash with Gaulish foes, a tale spun in the year 98. It was Julius Caesar who first carved the word “Germanus” into the annals of history in his writings on the Gallic Wars, demarcating the unconquered Germans from the subdued Gauls. The Gauls, it is said, uttered this name first, a label born of neighborly recognition or perhaps the spear they wielded, the ger, or from the Old Irish garim, the cry of battle echoing through the ages.

Tacitus, in his ancient script “De Origine et situ Germanorum,” spoke of the Germans as a people untouched by foreign tides, unmarred by the intermingling of races. He mused on why any soul would forsake the warmth of Asia or Africa, even Italy, for Germany's wild lands, its dour skies, unless it was indeed their home.

And who would abandon Rome for Germania? Not the Romans, not yet. Their ventures into Germania were for trade, for the spoils of land, and sometimes for conquest, but always they returned to the empire's warm embrace. As the first century unfurled, the Germanic tribes emerged at the empire's edge, trading their earth-born wares and pledging their martial prowess to Rome's legions, weaving their fates into the empire's grand tapestry. (Ozment, 2005, p. 17)

In the tale of Twelfth Night, the weave of deception stretches thin across the world like a shadow, and there’s a truth in it that cannot be escaped. That the guise donned for survival might be the very shroud that erases a soul. The danger lies not in the wearing but in the forsaking, for to shed that borrowed skin might leave one standing in a wilderness of solitude. And the choice comes down to the bitter bones of it: to hold onto oneself or to grasp at the threads of connection that fray with the revealing. Faces change like the tides and some may see the trickery with indifferent eyes, yet others will hold it close like a wound, sharp and unforgiving.

There’s a tangle in the reversal of roles, a question that circles like a hawk. Why does one abandon the self to walk in the skin of another? Viola, the lost wanderer on strange shores, wraps herself in the cloth of manhood, a cloak against the perils that stalk the unknown paths. Her ruse shields her, yet it builds a wall between her and the kinship of women, a gulf that grows with each passing day. She becomes a mirror to the world, reflecting not herself but the desires and confusions of those around her. Olivia, ensnared by the illusion, sees her brother in the face of Cesario and loves what is not there. “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.” (5.1.138) And there too is Orsino, tangled in the net of his own heart, speaking words that bind and unbind. “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.” (5.1. 260-261)

In the eyes of the now, Twelfth Night reveals the hidden currents beneath the calm waters, the truths that the masks of deception drag to the surface. Olivia and Orsino, each lost in their own reflections, find themselves face to face with the shadows they dared not name. Is it the semblance of manhood that draws Olivia, or is there a deeper truth she cannot see? Perhaps she is but a mirror of the age, a jest of those who see only the surface. For swiftly indeed does Olivia shift her affections to Sebastian, casting aside the illusion of Cesario for the reality of another, finding in Viola not a lover but a sister. “A sister, you are she.” (5.1.315) And so the play unwinds, revealing the heart of things, the choices made and unmade, in the light of a world that turns on the axis of its own deception.

In the shadowed annals of German dominion, there lies a tale of ruthless governance, one that saw the Ovaherero and Nama people pushed to the brink in the harsh expanse of German South West Africa. Yet to cast the entirety of an empire in so singular a hue is to overlook the variegated tapestry of its rule. The German colonial empire stretched across lands as diverse as its own methods, and within its borders, the matter of education took on many forms. When the British came to claim German East Africa in 1919, they uncovered a landscape peopled by Africans versed in letters and learning.
